central_thesis: Nicolas Remy's central thesis is to unequivocally prove the reality, heinousness, and pervasive nature of witchcraft, based on his extensive judicial experience and capital trials of over 900 accused individuals in Lorraine. The work aims to serve as an authoritative guide for magistrates and theologians, detailing the mechanisms, pacts, and interactions between witches and demons, thereby urging the relentless prosecution and condemnation of this crime.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter I: The Inducements by which Men may first be led astray by Demons, and so falling become Dealers in Magic.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details how demons tempt individuals through their lusts, poverty, desire for revenge, and other vices. It emphasizes that a formal break with one's baptismal pledge and an agreement to serve the Demon as Master are prerequisites for demonic aid. Temptations include fabricated beautiful bodies for pleasure, illusory riches, and drugs for poisoning enemies or healing friends, but primarily through fear and threats if persuasion fails.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter II: How Demons prepare, for those whom they have won by their Cunning, Drugged Powders, Wands, Ointments and Various Venoms of the sort: some of which cause Death, some only Sickness, and some even Healing.
structure_content.summary: Demons provide witches with powders (black for death, ashen/reddish for sickness, white for healing) and ointments. These substances are applied to clothes, food, drink, or directly to the body. Their efficacy is derived from demonic power, not inherent properties, and acts as a visible sign of the pact. Judges and magistrates are noted as being immune to these attacks.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter III: That Witches can with safety anoint their Hands and their entire Bodies with their Magic Ointments: yet if they but touch the Edge of a Person's Garment it will at once prove fatal to such a one, provided that it is the Witch's intent to Hurt.
structure_content.summary: Witches use magic ointments to apply poison, often by touching a victim's garment. Despite the poison's lethality, witches are immune to its effects on their bare hands. The harm inflicted is dependent on the witch's malevolent intent and demonic agency. This practice highlights the deceptive and insidious nature of witchcraft, where kindness can conceal harm.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter IV: That when Demons first approach their Followers, they bring them Money; but afterwards, when the Glamour has vanished, it is found to be nothing but Dung, Bricks, Leaves or some such Matter.
structure_content.summary: Demons entice followers with promises of wealth, but the money provided is illusory, reverting to worthless matter (dung, bricks, leaves, coal, stones) once the glamour fades. This deceit is a means to bind individuals to sin and establish demonic mastery, as true wealth would tempt even the righteous and facilitate further wickedness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter V: That it is not enough for Demons to hold Men bound and fettered by a Verbal Oath: but they furthermore mark them with their Talons as an Enduring Witness of the Servitude to which they have subjected them.
structure_content.summary: Beyond a verbal oath, demons physically brand their followers with a 'Devil's Mark' using their talons. This mark, often insensitive to pain and bleeding, serves as an undeniable token of servitude and allegiance to the demon, facilitating the recognition and recapture of witches. It is frequently located on areas of the body anointed during baptism.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter VI: That Demons lie with Men, but in a Manner which is Cold, Joyless, Vain and Barren. That they nevertheless celebrate Marriages, and even simulate and pretend Jealousy.
structure_content.summary: Demonic carnal relations (Incubi/Succubi) with humans are described as cold, rigid, joyless, painful, and barren, incapable of true procreation. These encounters are a deceitful simulation, often involving the demon assuming a body (e.g., a dead man's corpse or condensed vapours) and a monstrous member. The true purpose is sin and illusion, not natural propagation, with demons even simulating jealousy to bind witches more firmly.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter VII: That Demons condense for themselves a Body out of some Matter and assume the Shapes of various Living Things; and at times even take a Human Shape, but of a Low and Depraved Countenance, and always with their Hands and Feet hooked and bent like Birds of Prey.
structure_content.summary: Demons can assume tangible bodies from condensed air or vapours, taking various shapes. While they sometimes appear human, their forms are often hideous, with distorted features (deep-set flashing eyes, wide mouth, sulfurous smell, thin hands with talons, cloven feet, sometimes headless or missing a foot) and animalistic attributes (cats, hares, mice, dogs, crabs, wolves, goats). These forms are adopted to suit their immediate purpose, terrorize, or deceive.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter VIII: That Demons use the Speech of the Women with whom they Converse; but their Utterance is indistinct, thin, and a hoarse muffled Murmur.
structure_content.summary: Demons can mimic human speech, but their voices are typically indistinct, thin, hoarse, and muffled, often described as like 'a jar or cracked pitcher.' This imperfection serves to conceal their lies and reflect their inherent guilt. Witches confirm that their 'Little Masters' speak in their native tongue but with these characteristic vocal defects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter IX: That Satan often Deludes men by an Appearance of Righteousness; and he has his Disciples as skilled as Possible in the same Hypocrisy, that their Wickedness may be the more Secret and less open to Conjecture and Suspicion.
structure_content.summary: Satan deceives men by adopting a guise of righteousness, employing false piety, religious observances, and even self-torture. Witches, as his disciples, become skilled in hypocrisy, cloaking their crimes under a veneer of false devotion to avoid suspicion and appear saintly, drawing others into their cult. This deception is a core tactic to conceal the true, wicked nature of their practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter X: That the essential Filthiness of Demons is proved by the Fact that their Appearance is always accompanied by a Loathsome Stench; and that they so carefully instruct their Subjects to Avoid all Cleanliness, especially of the Hands, the Washing of which is a Hindrance to Witchcraft.
structure_content.summary: Demons are inherently impure, manifested by their foul stench and preference for unclean environments, including dead bodies. They instruct witches to avoid cleanliness, especially hand washing, as a ritual act. This avoidance of purity is a hindrance to the effectiveness of Christian prayers and a symbol of the demonic pact, reinforcing the corruption of the witch.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XI: That Witches, just as they are said to have done in Ancient Heathen Days, make yearly Offerings to their Demons for the purpose either of Averting the Menace of Blows, or of Winning Exemption from the less Pleasant of the Duties to which they are Pledged by their Pact. And that such Offerings, when they are Animals, must be entirely Black.
structure_content.summary: Witches offer yearly payments to demons, typically black animals (cocks, hens, steers, wethers), small gifts, or coins made of ox-hide, to avert punishment or gain exemption from Sabbat attendance or other duties. This practice, mirroring ancient pagan offerings, underscores the contractual nature of the demonic pact and the demons' preference for black offerings, symbolizing evil.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XII: That when Witches mean to Fly to their Sabbat, they Dupe the Jealousy of their Husbands by Charming them into a deep Sleep, or by Substituting some Object in their own Likeness to take their Place.
structure_content.summary: To attend Sabbats, witches employ charms to induce deep, unrousable sleep in their husbands or substitute inanimate objects (pillows, twigs) in their place to deceive them. This ensures their absence goes unnoticed, highlighting the witches' cunning and the demons' aid in facilitating their secret activities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XIII: That there are many Faults for which the Demons bring Witches to task with the utmost Severity; such as Failure to attend the Nocturnal Assemblies; the Healing of Diseases without Permission: suffering an Injury to be unavenged; Failure to do Evil; Stubbornness: dissuading another from Wrongdooing: confusing their Guilt to a Judge; using their Spells without Success; and very many other Shortcomings of this Kind. For these they are punished with the most Savage Beating, or else they must atone for them by some Serious Loss of their own Goods.
structure_content.summary: Demons rigorously punish witches for various transgressions, including missing Sabbats, healing without permission, failing to inflict harm, or confessing guilt under torture. Punishments range from savage beatings (sometimes near death, leaving physical scars) to infliction of sickness, or loss of their own goods, reflecting the demon's cruel and unjust mastery over its subjects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XIV: That Witches do often really and in fact Travel to their Nocturnal Synagogues; and often again such Journeyings are but an Empty Imagination begotten of Dreams; and that they are equally right who support either of these Opinions. Further, that these Journeys are performed in Various Manners; and on what Nights they most commonly take place in Lorraine.
structure_content.summary: Witches' journeys to Sabbats can be either real (physical transportation through the air, often on reeds, black dogs, or horses) or illusory (dream-like delusions). These journeys are painful and wearying. Sabbats in Lorraine commonly occur on Wednesday or Saturday nights. The author cites both physical evidence and detailed confessions to support the reality of these experiences, dispelling skepticism.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XV: That all kinds of Persons attend the Nocturnal Assemblies of Demons in Large Numbers; but the Majority of these are Women, since that Sex is the more susceptible to Evil Counsels.
structure_content.summary: Sabbats are attended by large numbers of people from all social classes, but women constitute the majority, attributed to their greater susceptibility to evil counsels. The sheer volume of attendees, as reported by witches, indicates the widespread nature of witchcraft.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XVI: That the Food placed before Witches at their Banquets is Tasteless and Mean, and not of a Kind to satisfy Hunger. That this has led many to the not Unnatural Opinion that these Feasts are a mere Vision and Phantasm; but that such is not always the case; for at times they do truly feed upon Human Flesh, Animals which have been found Dead, and other unwonted Meats of that Kind. But that they are always lacking in Salt and in Bread.
structure_content.summary: Sabbat banquets feature foul, tasteless, unsatisfying food, often consisting of human flesh, dead animals, or other refuse, deliberately lacking salt and bread. This absence is attributed to the demons' inherent antipathy towards purity and sacred rites (salt and bread being symbolic of holy things), and ensures the banquets remain a source of sin and illusion, not true sustenance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XVII: That the Dances, which were in Ancient Days performed in the Worship of Demons, are still used to-day at their Nocturnal Assemblies. That they cause far more Fatigue than the ordinary Dances of Men. Also that they are danced by Witches back to back in a Ring. That they are always a ready Source of Vice; and come little short of Madness.
structure_content.summary: Sabbat dances, often performed back-to-back in a ring, are extremely fatiguing and are linked to ancient pagan worship of demons. These dances are considered a primary source of vice and lead to madness, indicating their corrupting influence and the demons' strategy of stimulating human proclivities to sin.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XVIII: That Witches bind themselves by a Solemn Oath, which they repeat after the Demon himself, not to betray their Companions in Crime to the Judge. But they do not trust to that alone: for they take further Precautions against such a Risk by concealing their Names, and by covering their Faces with a Mask or Veil or some such thing.
structure_content.summary: Witches swear solemn oaths of silence to the Demon, promising not to betray their accomplices under torture. To further ensure secrecy and prevent recognition, they conceal their identities using masks or veils and avoid calling each other or the Demon by name. This highlights the emphasis on secrecy and mutual protection within the demonic cult.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XIX: However joyless and even ridiculous the Songs and Dances at the Demons' Assemblies, nevertheless the Witches on taking their Departure have to return Thanks as if they had enjoyed the greatest of Pleasure.
structure_content.summary: Despite the joyless, ridiculous, and fatiguing nature of Sabbat songs and dances, witches are compelled to feign pleasure and express gratitude to the Demon upon departure. This enforced performance maintains the illusion of satisfaction and reinforces the witch's commitment to the pact, preventing any display of discontent.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XX: That Demons order their Assemblies after the Manner of Men, and receive the customary Kiss of Homage from their Subjects; and that there is one of their Number who is the Chief, to whom such Honours are paid.
structure_content.summary: Sabbat assemblies are structured hierarchically, with a Chief Demon (referred to as 'Little Master') presiding from a throne. Witches approach with awe and trembling, performing an act of homage that involves falling prone and giving an 'obscene kiss' to the Demon's posteriors. This ritualistic submission emphasizes the inverted religious worship and absolute authority of the demon.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXI: That Demons often send upon the Fruits and Crops great Numbers of Small Animals of Different Sorts, which destroy and devour them in a Moment. And how this comes about.
structure_content.summary: Demons cause destruction to crops and fruits by sending swarms of small animals like caterpillars, bruchuses, locusts, or mice. This is part of the inherent hatred between demons and nature, aiming to spoil and destroy God's works. Witches assist in this by scattering powders or performing spells to invoke these pests and blights.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXII: That Witches must always have to report some Fresh Injury worked upon a Fellow-creature since their last Meeting; and they do not escape Punishment if they come to the next Meeting guiltless of some Crime of Witchcraft.
structure_content.summary: Witches are obligated to report new crimes and injuries inflicted since their last Sabbat, facing severe punishment from demons if they fail to increase their wickedness. Demons hold 'classes' to instruct witches in various malefic arts, such as crop destruction, bewitching flocks, poisoning, and spreading disease, ensuring their continuous engagement in evil deeds.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXIII: That Demons change themselves for the time into the Shapes of Various Animals according to their Requirements. And when they wish to mix with their Subjects they nearly always assume the Shape of a Goat, especially when they publicly manifest themselves in order to be Worshipped and Revered.
structure_content.summary: Demons frequently assume animal shapes, particularly that of a goat, when manifesting for worship, reflecting their 'essential baseness' and 'obscene lasciviousness.' This shape is chosen for public display and reverence, while other forms (cats, flies) are used for more discreet tasks like whispering warnings to witches.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXIV: The Transvection of Men through the Air by Good Angels, of which we read in Time past, was calm and free from Labour; but that by which Witches are now transported by Demons is full of Pain and Weariness.
structure_content.summary: Demonic transportation through the air is described as painful and wearying, contrasting with the peaceful transportations by good angels. Witches are carried on black dogs, horses, or reeds, or borne aloft in thick clouds. This distinction underscores the baleful nature of demonic intervention compared to divine assistance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXV: However incredible it may appear, yet all Witches with one Voice declare that they are often endued by their Demons with the Power of raising the Clouds; and that, being borne up in these, they drive and thrust them whither they will, and even, if nothing obstructs them, shake them down in Rain upon the Earth. Together with the Circumstances mentioned by them as Necessary and Peculiar to the Accomplishment of this Matter.
structure_content.summary: Witches claim the power to raise storms, hail, and rain with demonic aid. This involves rituals such as stirring water with a wand, using black candles to drip wax, and scattering drugged powders. They are then borne aloft in thick clouds, steering tempests and causing hail to fall upon designated areas, emphasizing the demons' control over natural phenomena.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXVI: The Sounds of Bell, because they call Men to Holy Prayer, is odious and baleful to Demons; and it is not without Cause that Bells are often rung when Hailstorms and other Tempests, in which Witches' Work is suspected, are brooding and threatening.
structure_content.summary: Demons detest the sound of church bells, as they call men to holy prayer and are believed to thwart demonic purposes. The ringing of bells during storms, especially hailstorms, is an ancient Christian custom recognized as a protection against witchcraft, highlighting the spiritual conflict between divine and demonic forces.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXVII: That which is struck by Lightning is often seen to be Marked and Scored as it were by Claws; and this has led many to believe that the Demon plays some Part in it. For it is thought that, when he assumes a Body, he prefers to take one provided with Claws and Talons after the Manner of the Wild Beasts.
structure_content.summary: Marks left by lightning strikes on trees, walls, or roofs are attributed to the claws and talons of demons. This observation suggests that when demons assume a body, they prefer forms equipped with such features, reinforcing their fierce and destructive nature. The author posits a demonic agency behind natural phenomena typically ascribed to natural causes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXVIII: They are in Error who, following the Epicureans, deny that Demons accost Men, tempt them with their Offers, strike them with Terror, set Snares for them, and are Evil, Baleful and Injurious to Men; for the Truth of this is shown in countless Stories both Sacred and Profane; and it is confirmed by the unanimous Statements of our Witches of to-day.
structure_content.summary: Remy refutes Epicurean skepticism regarding demons, affirming their active role in accosting, tempting, striking terror, and injuring men. He supports this assertion with numerous stories from sacred and profane history, further corroborated by the unanimous confessions of witches in his trials, establishing the malevolent and tangible nature of demonic interaction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I, Chapter XXIX: Not only are Witches, as has already been said, carried through the Air by Demons; but being in the Air they devise and work much Harm to Men: and finally they are gently and quietly placed down upon the Ground, even as Birds alight.
structure_content.summary: This chapter reiterates and confirms that witches are transported through the air by demons and, while airborne, actively devise and inflict harm upon men. Upon completion of their aerial tasks, they are gently placed back on the ground. This highlights the operational aspect of aerial travel in the execution of malefic witchcraft.

key_concepts.definition: The worship or servitude to demons, explicitly equated with witchcraft and heresy, forming the central crime investigated by Remy.

A practice initiated by a pact with the Devil, involving a transfer of allegiance and resulting in the witch gaining power to inflict harm or perform illusions through demonic aid. It is a tangible crime prosecuted by law.

A physical, insensitive mark (often on baptismal sites) made by the demon's talons on the witch's body, serving as an undeniable token of servitude and allegiance, and a means for recognition and recapture.

Substances (powders of various colors, ointments) provided by demons to witches, used for purposes such as causing sickness, death, or healing, and for aerial travel. Their potency is derived from demonic power, not intrinsic properties.

Secret gatherings of witches and demons, characterized by foul banquets (lacking salt and bread, sometimes involving human flesh), back-to-back dances, indistinct demonic speech, oaths of silence, and worship of a Chief Demon.

Demons that engage in carnal relations with humans (Incubi with women, Succubi with men). These encounters are described as cold, rigid, joyless, painful, and barren, primarily serving as a means of deception and sin rather than natural procreation.

The ability of demons (and witches through them) to change shapes (e.g., animals, deformed humans) or to make objects *appear* to change. Remy asserts these are always illusions or glamours, not true physical transformations.

A magical method used by witches, facilitated by demons, to induce a deep, unrousable sleep in individuals (e.g., husbands) or substitute objects (e.g., pillows, twigs) to facilitate secret activities like Sabbat attendance.

Verbal or ritualistic actions performed by witches, always with demonic assistance and malevolent intent, to inflict sickness, death, crop destruction, bewitchment, or other misfortunes upon individuals, animals, or property.

A ritual act of absolute submission performed by witches to the Chief Demon at the Sabbat, typically involving kneeling, joining hands, and an 'obscene kiss' to the demon's posteriors, symbolizing total fealty.

practical_system.description: Remy's work documents the 'practical system' of witchcraft from an external, adversarial, and judicial perspective, rather than providing instructions for practice. This 'system' revolves around a demonic pact, conceived as an inversion of Christian sacraments. Initiates acquire malefic tools and abilities from demons, allowing them to inflict harm or create illusions. Key to the system are nocturnal assemblies (Sabbats) for worship, carnal relations with demons, learning new dark arts, and reporting accomplished crimes. While witches perform physical actions (e.g., spreading powders), their power is entirely derived from demonic agency. The overarching goal for the demon is the corruption and destruction of humanity, and for the witch, the satisfaction of base desires, vengeance, or escape from poverty, secured through their servitude and the promise of illusory rewards.
tools: Drugged Powders (black for death, ashen/reddish for sickness, white for healing)
Magic Ointments (for aerial travel and causing harm)
Wands, sticks, and reeds (for various spells, including storm-raising and aerial transport)
Substitute objects (pillows, twigs) for deceiving sleeping husbands
Various herbs, straws, and trash (used in malefic spells)
Iron or brass pins (for probing the Devil's Mark)
rituals: Entering into a demonic pact involving an inverted baptismal pledge and a physical mark by the demon's talons.
Attending nocturnal Sabbats through aerial transportation (on reeds, black dogs, or horses, or via summoned clouds) or through inducing a charmed sleep in others.
Participating in ritual banquets featuring foul, tasteless food (often human flesh, lacking salt/bread).
Performing back-to-back dances in a ring at Sabbats.
Offering homage to a Chief Demon through kneeling, joined hands, and an 'obscene kiss' to the posteriors.
Inflicting curses and spells through scattering powders, anointing objects, or verbal maledictions, often requiring the witch's explicit consent.
Making yearly offerings of black animals or other small gifts to demons to avert punishment or gain exemptions from duties.
Concealing identity at Sabbats with masks, veils, or false names.

relevant_quotes.text: DEMONOLATRY by NICOLAS REMY Privy Councillor to The Most Serene Duke of Lorraine, and Public Advocate to his Duchy Translated by E. A. ASHWIN + Edited with Introduction and Notes by the REV. MONTAGUE SUMMERS DRAWN FROM THE CAPITAL TRIALS OF 900 PERSONS, MORE OR LESS, WHO WITHIN THE LAST FIFTEEN YEARS HAVE IN LORRAINE PAID THE PENALTY OF DEATH FOR THE CRIME OF WITCHCRAFT

And for my part, since my lot has been for so many years to conduct the trial of capital offences in Lorraine, it has seemed that there is no course left me but to publish the truth of all the prodigious tales that are told of this sort of witchcraft, particularly such as have come within my own experience in my examination of cases which have passed through my own hands.

From the very beginning the Devil was a murderer (S. John viii), and never has he ceased to tempt the impious to commit slaughter and parricide. Therefore it is no wonder that, once he has caught men in his toils, his first care is to furnish them with the implements and instruct them in the practices of witchcraft.
The commonest practice of all witches is to fly up through the chimney.

They who swear fealty to their feudal Lord do so by falling on their knees before him, giving the required kiss and placing their joined hands between his hands, thus symbolizing a lowly and willing obedience of spirit; and the Demons most strictly exact a similar homage from their subjects whenever they hold their assemblies, although the ceremony is conducted in the strangest and most degraded manner, as is everything else that they do.

critical_analysis.relevance: "Demonolatry" is a foundational text in the historical study of demonology and witchcraft trials. Its primary significance lies in being one of the most comprehensive and 'operative' treatises written by a secular magistrate (Nicolas Remy) with extensive first-hand experience in prosecuting witchcraft cases in early modern Lorraine. Remy's legal background gives his accounts a unique, albeit inherently biased, perspective, grounding his detailed descriptions of alleged witch practices in legal testimonies and trial records. The book is not a philosophical exploration but a practical manual for identifying, prosecuting, and understanding witchcraft as a tangible crime, providing invaluable insight into the socio-legal-theological understanding of the phenomenon during a critical period of witch-hunts.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary intended audience for this work was contemporary magistrates, judges, and legal professionals in Lorraine and other European regions. It provided them with an authoritative guide for conducting witchcraft trials, understanding the 'operative' mechanisms of witchcraft, and justifying the severe penalties for accused witches. It also served as a theological and moral warning to the general populace about the dangers of demonic influence and the necessity of Christian piety. For modern esoteric and occult practitioners, it offers a crucial window into the historical perception of black magic and demonolatry, particularly useful for contextual understanding in the study of grimoire traditions and historical magical practices, rather than as a guide for emulation.
